title: Reducing Noise with Augmented Reality: Perceptual Experience and Evaluation
author: Clara Boukhemia (IRCAM), Nicolas Misdariis (IRCAM), Mathieu Lagrange (CNRS), Antoine Gonot (IRCAM), Mitsuko Aramaki (IRCAM)
relevance_why: The exploration of auditory masking techniques could inform new strategies for audio quality enhancement and environment optimization in Haohe's research.
background: This research investigates methods to reduce unpleasant sound impacts in indoor environments using augmented reality techniques, focusing on real-time auditory adjustments.
contribution: This paper introduces the auditory concealer approach to solve issues related to noise pollution in office settings, achieving insights into user preference for different soundscapes.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods have largely focused on auditory masking techniques that primarily seek to cover noise without considering user preferences regarding sound quality.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon existing masking methods by introducing an experimental approach that specifically analyzes user enjoyment of the soundscapes created.

key_innovation: It identifies the balance between noise reduction and user enjoyment, thus proposing a more user-centered approach to managing acoustic environments.
real_world_impact: The findings could potentially enhance workplace environments by reducing noise-related stress, improving productivity, and ensuring better overall auditory comfort for users.
limitations: The study primarily focuses on specific environments and noise sources, which may limit generalizability to other contexts.

new_terms.auditory concealer: **Auditory concealer** refers to a form of sound management aimed at improving the perceived quality of noisy environments by blending or masking annoying sounds with more pleasant ones.
new_terms.masking: **Masking** is a technique used in audio processing where a sound is covered by another sound to make it less perceptible or distracting.
